blockTitle: Prepares and Assembles Tube, Tubing and Pipe

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What is the first step when inspecting copper tubing upon delivery?

options.A: Measure the wall thickness with calipers
options.B: Check for physical damage, dents, and verify correct size and type
options.D: Apply pressure to test for leaks

explanations.A: Wall thickness measurement is important but comes after visual inspection for obvious damage and specification verification.
explanations.B: Initial inspection includes visual examination for shipping damage, dents, kinks, and verification that materials match specifications before acceptance.
explanations.C: Hardness testing is not a standard field inspection procedure; visual inspection and specification verification are the primary acceptance criteria.
explanations.D: Pressure testing occurs after installation, not during receipt inspection of unused materials.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What defect in copper tubing would make it unacceptable for potable water use?

options.B: Slight discoloration from oxidation
options.C: Deep dents or kinks that reduce internal diameter

explanations.A: Minor surface scratches do not affect structural integrity or water quality if they don't penetrate the wall.
explanations.B: Surface oxidation is normal and does not affect tubing integrity or water quality; it can be cleaned if necessary.
explanations.C: Dents or kinks that reduce internal diameter create flow restrictions, stress concentrations, and potential failure points making the tubing unacceptable.
explanations.D: Manufacturer's markings are required identification and do not affect tubing suitability for use.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: When inspecting threaded steel pipe, what thread condition would require rejection?

options.B: Crossed, stripped, or damaged threads
options.C: Threads with a light oil coating

explanations.A: Minor handling marks that don't damage thread form are acceptable; threads must engage properly for leak-free joints.
explanations.B: Crossed, stripped, or damaged threads cannot form proper sealing joints and will leak regardless of sealant applied.
explanations.C: Light oil coating protects threads during storage and is normal; it should be cleaned before applying thread sealant.
explanations.D: Minor surface rust can be cleaned with a wire brush; rejection is only necessary if rust has caused pitting or thread damage.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What must be verified when inspecting plastic pipe before installation?

options.A: That it has been stored at freezing temperatures
options.B: Material type, size, rating, and absence of cracks or deformation

explanations.A: Plastic pipe should be stored at moderate temperatures; freezing can cause brittleness or damage to some plastic types.
explanations.B: Inspection must verify correct material type (PVC, CPVC, PEX), size, pressure rating, and check for cracks, deformation, or UV damage.
explanations.C: Flotation is not an inspection criterion; material specifications, physical condition, and ratings determine suitability.
explanations.D: While color coding helps identify pipe types, the critical factors are material specifications, ratings, and physical condition.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: Why must pipe ends be inspected for proper cutting before installation?

options.A: To verify the pipe length matches specifications
options.B: To ensure cuts are square, deburred, and free of damage
options.C: To check if the pipe was cut with approved tools

explanations.A: Length verification is separate from cut quality inspection; end condition affects joint integrity regardless of length.
explanations.B: Square cuts ensure proper fitting engagement, while deburring prevents flow restriction, turbulence, and gasket damage.
explanations.C: Tool type is less important than the quality of the resulting cut; various tools can produce acceptable cuts if used properly.
explanations.D: Cutting date is irrelevant; the physical condition of the cut and preparation quality are the critical inspection factors.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What should be checked when inspecting compression fittings before installation?

options.A: That the ferrule is present, undamaged, and properly sized
options.B: That the fitting has been previously used

explanations.A: Compression fittings require undamaged ferrules of correct size to create leak-free seals; missing or damaged ferrules will cause leaks.
explanations.B: Compression fittings should not be reused as ferrules deform during initial installation and will not seal properly if reinstalled.
explanations.C: Manufacturing date is not a primary inspection concern for fittings; physical condition and proper components are critical.
explanations.D: Compression fittings use standard right-hand threads; thread direction is not a variable requiring verification.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: When inspecting cast iron pipe, what surface condition indicates the pipe should be rejected?

options.A: Gray color typical of cast iron
options.B: Deep cracks, holes, or honeycombing in the pipe wall

explanations.A: Gray coloring is normal for cast iron and indicates proper material; color itself is not a rejection criterion.
explanations.B: Cracks, holes, or honeycombing (porosity) compromise structural integrity and leak resistance, requiring pipe rejection.
explanations.C: Some surface roughness is inherent to cast iron manufacturing and does not affect structural integrity or function.
explanations.D: Manufacturer's markings are required for identification and quality assurance; their presence is desirable, not a defect.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What must be verified when inspecting solder fittings for copper tubing?

options.A: That fittings have been pre-soldered at the factory
options.B: Socket depth, proper size, and absence of dents or damage

explanations.A: Solder fittings are not pre-soldered; they require field soldering during installation after proper preparation.
explanations.B: Socket depth must accommodate tubing properly, size must match, and fittings must be undamaged for proper joint formation.
explanations.C: Copper fittings are non-magnetic; magnetic properties are not relevant to copper fitting inspection.
explanations.D: Individual fitting weight is not a field inspection criterion; visual inspection and dimensional verification are the standard checks.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: Why is it important to inspect the interior of pipe and fittings before installation?

options.A: To verify the pipe color matches
options.B: To remove debris, scale, and foreign material that could contaminate the system
options.C: To measure the exact internal diameter
options.D: To check for manufacturer defects only

explanations.A: Interior color is not visible during use and is not an inspection concern; cleanliness and freedom from debris are critical.
explanations.B: Interior inspection ensures removal of manufacturing debris, scale, and contamination that could clog fixtures, damage equipment, or contaminate water.
explanations.C: While internal diameter is important, it's verified by size markings; inspection focuses on cleanliness and absence of obstructions.
explanations.D: Interior inspection addresses both manufacturing defects and accumulated contamination from handling and storage.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What type of damage to plastic pipe indicates UV degradation requiring rejection?

options.B: Chalky, brittle surface with discoloration and cracking

explanations.A: Surface dirt is easily cleaned and does not indicate material degradation or affect pipe integrity.
explanations.B: UV exposure causes surface chalking, brittleness, discoloration, and cracking in plastics, compromising strength and requiring rejection.
explanations.C: Condensation is a temporary environmental condition unrelated to UV damage or pipe integrity.
explanations.D: While faded labels may indicate UV exposure, the critical factor is physical degradation of the pipe material itself.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: When inspecting flanged pipe fittings, what must be checked on the flange face?

options.A: That the flange face is smooth, flat, and free from gouges or warping
options.B: That the flange has been painted
options.C: The thickness of the flange only

explanations.A: Flange faces must be smooth and flat without gouges or warping to allow gaskets to seal properly and prevent leaks.
explanations.B: Painting may be required for corrosion protection but is not a primary inspection criterion for the sealing surface.
explanations.C: Flange thickness is a design specification already determined; face condition is the critical inspection factor for leak prevention.
explanations.D: Bolt holes should be standard size with proper tolerance; oversized holes indicate damage or improper manufacturing.

questions.subtask: B-6.01 Inspects tube, tubing, pipe and fittings before installation
questions.question: What pressure rating information must be verified during pipe inspection?

options.A: That all pipe has the same color coding
options.B: That the pipe pressure rating meets or exceeds system requirements
options.C: That the pipe was manufactured locally
options.D: That the pipe has been previously tested

explanations.A: Color coding helps identification but does not determine pressure capability; marked ratings are the definitive specification.
explanations.B: Pipe pressure rating must meet or exceed system design pressure to prevent failure; using under-rated pipe creates dangerous conditions.
explanations.C: Manufacturing location is irrelevant provided materials meet specifications and standards; ratings determine suitability.
explanations.D: New pipe is not pre-tested; system testing occurs after installation to verify complete assembly integrity.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the recommended cutting tool for rigid copper tubing to produce the cleanest cut?

options.B: Tubing cutter with sharp cutting wheel

explanations.A: Hacksaws produce acceptable cuts but require more deburring and may not be as square as tubing cutter cuts.
explanations.B: Tubing cutters produce clean, square cuts with minimal burrs, reducing preparation time and ensuring proper fitting engagement.
explanations.C: Reciprocating saws cut quickly but produce rough edges requiring extensive deburring and may not achieve square cuts.
explanations.D: Abrasive wheels create heat and metal dust contamination; they're not recommended for tubing that will carry potable water.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why should you avoid over-tightening a tubing cutter when cutting copper?

options.A: To prevent damage to the cutting wheel
options.B: To prevent deformation of the tubing and internal lip formation
options.C: To speed up the cutting process

explanations.A: While excessive force can damage the wheel, the primary concern is tubing deformation affecting joint quality.
explanations.B: Over-tightening causes tubing to deform and creates an internal lip (roll) that restricts flow and must be reamed out.
explanations.C: Gradual tightening actually produces better cuts than aggressive tightening; speed is not improved by over-tightening.
explanations.D: Noise reduction is not a factor in proper cutting technique; preventing deformation is the critical concern.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What must be done immediately after cutting any pipe or tubing?

options.A: Apply primer to the cut end
options.B: Deburr and remove sharp edges and internal burrs
options.D: Store the pipe in a vertical position

explanations.A: Primer application is specific to certain plastic pipe joints and comes after deburring, not immediately after cutting.
explanations.B: Deburring removes sharp edges that could injure workers and internal burrs that restrict flow or damage seals.
explanations.C: Painting is a finishing step for certain applications and is not required immediately after cutting.
explanations.D: Storage position is unrelated to cut preparation; deburring is the critical immediate step after cutting.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When cutting plastic pipe with a handsaw, what blade type should be used?

options.B: Fine-tooth blade to prevent chipping and cracking

explanations.A: Coarse-tooth blades tear plastic rather than cutting cleanly, causing chips and cracks at the cut edge.
explanations.B: Fine-tooth blades make clean cuts in plastic without chipping or cracking, producing edges suitable for proper joint preparation.
explanations.C: While metal-cutting blades work, the critical factor is fine teeth; plastic-specific blades may actually perform better.
explanations.D: Blade selection affects cut quality significantly; wrong blades damage plastic requiring extensive rework.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the proper technique when using a pipe cutter on steel pipe?

options.A: Tighten fully and make one complete rotation
options.B: Rotate the cutter around the pipe, gradually tightening after each rotation
options.D: Tighten until the pipe is crushed, then back off slightly

explanations.A: Full tightening in one step crushes the pipe; gradual tightening with rotation produces clean cuts without deformation.
explanations.B: Gradual tightening after each rotation allows the cutting wheel to progressively cut through the pipe wall without crushing.
explanations.C: Pipe cutters work by rotation around the pipe; straight pushing is not possible with rotary cutting tools.
explanations.D: Crushing the pipe creates deformation requiring extensive reaming; proper technique prevents this problem.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why is cutting cast iron pipe with snap cutters preferred over sawing?

options.A: Snap cutters are less expensive than saws
options.B: Snap cutters produce clean breaks and minimal dust compared to sawing
options.C: Snap cutters work on any pipe size

explanations.A: Cost is not the primary advantage; clean cutting and dust control are the key benefits of snap cutters.
explanations.B: Snap cutters break cast iron cleanly along a scored line with minimal dust, unlike sawing which creates harmful dust.
explanations.C: Snap cutters have size limitations; very large diameter cast iron must be cut with other methods.
explanations.D: All tools require maintenance; the advantage is cutting quality and dust control, not maintenance elimination.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What safety precaution is essential when cutting pipe with power tools?

options.B: Wear appropriate eye protection and secure the pipe properly
options.D: Stand directly in line with the blade

explanations.A: Adequate lighting is essential for safe operation; working in darkness increases accident risk significantly.
explanations.B: Eye protection prevents injury from flying debris, and securing pipe prevents movement that could cause tool binding or kickback.
explanations.C: Appropriate cutting speed maintains control; excessive speed increases heat, tool wear, and accident risk.
explanations.D: Standing in line with cutting tools creates severe injury risk from kickback or blade failure; position yourself to the side.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When cutting PVC pipe, at what temperature should cutting be avoided?

options.D: Temperature does not affect PVC cutting

explanations.A: Above 15°C is normal working temperature; PVC cuts well at moderate temperatures.
explanations.B: This temperature range is ideal for cutting PVC; brittleness is not a concern in this range.
explanations.C: Cold temperatures make PVC brittle and prone to cracking during cutting; warm pipe to above 0°C before cutting if possible.
explanations.D: Temperature significantly affects PVC properties; cold makes it brittle while extreme heat makes it soft.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of using a reamer after cutting copper tubing?

options.B: To remove the internal burr and restore full internal diameter
options.C: To create threads inside the tubing

explanations.A: Reamers work on internal surfaces to remove burrs; exterior polishing is not the purpose of reaming.
explanations.B: Reaming removes the internal lip and burrs created during cutting, restoring full flow diameter and preventing turbulence.
explanations.C: Copper tubing is not threaded internally; it uses solder, compression, or press fittings for connections.
explanations.D: Marking occurs before cutting; reaming is a post-cutting operation to remove burrs.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When cutting multiple pieces of pipe to the same length, what method ensures accuracy?

options.A: Estimate by eye for each piece
options.B: Use a template or measuring jig to mark all pieces consistently
options.C: Cut one piece short and adjust others longer
options.D: Rely on the saw's built-in measurement

explanations.A: Visual estimation introduces significant variation; precise measurement is necessary for consistent results.
explanations.B: Templates or jigs ensure all pieces are marked and cut to identical lengths, eliminating measurement errors.
explanations.C: Intentional variation defeats the purpose of cutting to consistent lengths; precision requires accurate measurement.
explanations.D: Most cutting saws do not have built-in measurement systems; separate measuring and marking is required.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why should threaded pipe be cut with a specific allowance beyond the measured length?

options.A: To account for thread engagement length into fittings
options.B: To provide extra material for future modifications
options.C: To reduce the weight of the pipe

explanations.A: Thread engagement (typically 1/2 to 3/4 inch per end) must be added to measured length so threaded ends enter fittings properly.
explanations.B: While some allowance for adjustments is wise, thread engagement is a specific dimensional requirement, not a general allowance.
explanations.C: Weight reduction is not achieved by cutting allowances; proper length calculation ensures joints assemble correctly.
explanations.D: Appearance is not a factor in thread engagement calculations; proper joint assembly is the critical concern.

questions.subtask: B-6.02 Cuts tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What problem can occur if pipe is not cut square to its centerline?

options.B: Fittings will not seat properly, causing potential leaks and misalignment
options.C: The pipe will be more flexible
options.D: The pipe color will fade faster

explanations.A: Cut angle does not affect pipe weight; weight is determined by material and dimensions.
explanations.B: Non-square cuts prevent complete fitting engagement, create stress concentration, and allow leaks at improperly seated joints.
explanations.C: Flexibility is a material property unaffected by cut angle; proper fitting engagement is the concern with angled cuts.
explanations.D: Color stability is unrelated to cut quality; proper fitting engagement and leak prevention are the critical issues.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the minimum bend radius for copper tubing to prevent kinking?

options.A: One times the tubing outside diameter
options.B: Three to five times the tubing outside diameter
options.C: Ten times the tubing outside diameter
options.D: Any radius is acceptable with enough force

explanations.A: One diameter is too sharp and will cause kinking, wall thinning, and collapse of the tubing.
explanations.B: Minimum bend radius of 3-5 times the outside diameter prevents kinking and maintains wall integrity during bending.
explanations.C: Ten times diameter is very conservative and often unnecessary; proper radius is 3-5 times for most applications.
explanations.D: Sharp bends will kink regardless of force applied; minimum radius must be maintained to prevent tubing collapse.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When should a tube bender be used instead of making a hand bend?

options.A: For all bends regardless of size
options.B: When precise angles and radius control are needed, especially for rigid tubing
options.C: Only for steel pipe, never for copper

explanations.A: Very gentle bends in soft tubing can be made by hand; benders are necessary for controlled angles and rigid materials.
explanations.B: Tube benders provide controlled radius and precise angles, preventing kinking especially in rigid or large diameter tubing.
explanations.C: Tube benders work with various materials including copper, steel, and aluminum; material does not determine if benders are needed.
explanations.D: Hand bending is limited to soft materials and gentle curves; most installations require the precision of bending tools.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of using internal spring benders for soft copper tubing?

options.A: To make the tubing more rigid
options.B: To support the tubing walls and prevent collapse during bending
options.D: To eliminate the need for measurements

explanations.A: Spring benders provide temporary support during bending; they do not permanently change tubing properties.
explanations.B: Internal springs support tubing walls during bending, preventing kinking and collapse while allowing uniform radius formation.
explanations.C: Spring benders actually allow tighter bends by preventing collapse; they support the walls rather than increase radius.
explanations.D: Springs provide mechanical support during bending but do not eliminate the need for proper angle and length measurements.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why should bends be avoided near solder joints in copper installations?

options.B: Heat from soldering can weaken tubing at bend locations
options.C: Solder will flow into bent sections
options.D: Bends are incompatible with solder joints

explanations.A: Color changes are cosmetic and not a structural concern; heat effects on bent material are the critical issue.
explanations.B: Bending work-hardens copper; subsequent heating during soldering can cause stress relief and potential failure at the bend.
explanations.C: Solder flows to fill gaps in joints, not along tubing length; flow into bends is not a concern.
explanations.D: Bends and solder joints are compatible if properly spaced; the concern is heat effect on work-hardened bent material.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What happens to the wall thickness when tubing is bent?

options.A: Wall thickness remains uniform throughout the bend
options.B: Outside of bend becomes thinner, inside becomes thicker
options.C: Inside of bend becomes thinner, outside becomes thicker

explanations.A: Bending stretches the outside and compresses the inside, necessarily changing wall thickness distribution.
explanations.B: The outside radius stretches and thins while the inside radius compresses and thickens during bending.
explanations.C: This reverses the actual effect; stretching thins material while compression thickens it.
explanations.D: Overall material volume is constant; redistribution occurs with thinning in tension areas and thickening in compression areas.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When bending PEX tubing, what characteristic allows tight radius bends?

options.A: PEX is rigid and resists bending
options.B: PEX flexibility and memory allow tight bends without special tools
options.C: PEX must be heated before any bending
options.D: PEX cannot be bent under any circumstances

explanations.A: PEX is highly flexible compared to rigid materials; flexibility is one of its primary advantages.
explanations.B: PEX's flexibility allows tight radius bends by hand, and its memory helps maintain bend shape without permanent deformation.
explanations.C: PEX bends easily at room temperature; heating may be used for special applications but is not required for normal bending.
explanations.D: PEX's flexibility is a key feature; it bends easily and is often chosen specifically for this characteristic.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What tool is used to make precise multiple bends in rigid conduit and tubing?

options.B: Hydraulic or mechanical tube bender with degree markings
options.D: Cutting torch to heat the bend area

explanations.A: Hammers and anvils produce uncontrolled bends with kinking; precision bending requires specialized tools.
explanations.B: Hydraulic or mechanical benders with degree markings allow precise, repeatable bends at controlled angles and radii.
explanations.C: Hand tools cannot apply sufficient controlled force for precision bending of rigid materials without causing damage.
explanations.D: Heat bending is used for some plastics and thick-wall pipe, but mechanical benders provide better control and consistency.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why should you avoid over-bending and then bending back to correct the angle?

options.B: Work hardening and fatigue from multiple bends can cause cracking
options.C: The tubing will become permanently discolored

explanations.A: While time is wasted, the critical issue is material damage from repeated stress cycles.
explanations.B: Each bending operation work-hardens the material; reversing bends creates fatigue that can lead to cracking and failure.
explanations.C: Discoloration may occur but is cosmetic; structural damage from fatigue is the serious concern.
explanations.D: Multiple bends weaken material through work hardening and fatigue; they do not improve strength.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the maximum number of 90-degree bends typically allowed between pull points in continuous tubing runs?

options.B: Two 90-degree bends (180 degrees total)

explanations.A: One bend is overly restrictive; multiple bends are acceptable within limits to maintain reasonable pulling force.
explanations.B: Two 90-degree bends are acceptable but not the maximum; the limit is typically higher.
explanations.C: Four 90-degree bends (360 degrees total) is typically the maximum to maintain reasonable pulling forces and prevent tubing damage.
explanations.D: Excessive bends create too much friction for pulling wires or cleaning; practical limits exist based on pulling forces.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: When bending aluminum tubing, what special consideration is required?

options.A: Aluminum cannot be bent under any circumstances
options.B: Aluminum is softer than copper and requires careful support to prevent collapse
options.C: Aluminum is harder than steel and needs no special care
options.D: Aluminum must be heated red-hot before bending

explanations.A: Aluminum tubing can be bent successfully with proper techniques and tools; it requires more care than some materials.
explanations.B: Aluminum's softness makes it prone to collapse during bending; proper mandrels or fillers are essential for quality bends.
explanations.C: Aluminum is actually softer than many materials and requires more support during bending to prevent collapse.
explanations.D: Aluminum does not require red-hot heating for bending; it can be bent cold with proper support tools.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of annealing copper tubing before bending?

options.A: To make the copper harder and stronger
options.B: To soften work-hardened copper, making it easier to bend

explanations.A: Annealing is a softening process that reduces hardness; hardening requires different heat treatment processes.
explanations.B: Annealing heats and slowly cools copper to relieve work hardening, making it softer and easier to bend without cracking.
explanations.C: While heating may cause discoloration, this is a side effect; the purpose is to soften the material.
explanations.D: Annealing affects material structure and hardness; it does not repair existing cracks or seal them.

questions.subtask: B-6.03 Bends tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why must the proper size tube bender die be used for each tubing size?

options.A: To match tubing color to die color
options.B: To ensure correct bend radius and prevent collapse or wrinkling
options.D: Dies are interchangeable for all sizes

explanations.A: Color coding may help organization but die size determines bend quality; matching colors is not a functional requirement.
explanations.B: Proper die size provides correct radius support, prevents collapse on the inside radius, and controls stretching on the outside.
explanations.C: While proper dies may improve efficiency, their primary purpose is producing quality bends without defects.
explanations.D: Dies are size-specific; using incorrect dies produces poor quality bends with collapse, wrinkling, or excessive thinning.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What must be done to copper tubing before soldering?

options.B: Clean and polish mating surfaces to remove oxides and contamination
options.C: Roughen the surface with a file
options.D: Apply oil to the joint area

explanations.A: Paint prevents solder bonding; surfaces must be clean bare metal for proper capillary action and bonding.
explanations.B: Cleaning removes oxides and contamination that prevent solder wetting and bonding; bright, clean copper is essential.
explanations.C: Polishing smooths surfaces; roughening creates gaps that prevent proper capillary action in solder joints.
explanations.D: Oil and grease prevent solder bonding; surfaces must be completely clean and free of all contamination.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What is the purpose of applying flux to copper joints before soldering?

options.A: To cool the joint after heating
options.B: To remove and prevent oxide formation, allowing solder to wet surfaces
options.C: To increase the melting point of solder
options.D: To provide structural strength to the joint

explanations.A: Flux is applied before heating to prepare surfaces; cooling occurs naturally after soldering is complete.
explanations.B: Flux chemically cleans surfaces, prevents new oxide formation during heating, and allows solder to wet and bond properly.
explanations.C: Flux does not change solder melting point; it prepares surfaces for bonding at the solder's normal melting temperature.
explanations.D: Solder provides joint strength; flux is a chemical cleaner that enables proper solder bonding but adds no strength itself.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: When preparing threaded pipe connections, what must be applied to the threads?

options.B: Thread sealant compound or PTFE tape

explanations.A: Threads alone do not seal; spiral leak paths exist between thread roots and crests requiring sealant.
explanations.B: Thread sealant or PTFE tape fills spiral leak paths in threads, creating pressure-tight, leak-free joints.
explanations.C: Grease and oil may lubricate but do not seal; proper thread sealants are required for pressure-tight joints.
explanations.D: Rubber cement is not a pipe thread sealant; approved thread compounds or PTFE tape are required.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: How should PTFE tape be applied to pipe threads?

options.A: Counter-clockwise when viewing the end of the pipe
options.B: Clockwise when viewing the end of the pipe, in the direction of thread engagement
options.D: Wrapped around the outside of the fitting

explanations.A: Counter-clockwise application causes tape to unwrap and bunch during fitting engagement, preventing proper sealing.
explanations.B: Clockwise application (viewing from the end) ensures tape tightens and embeds into threads during clockwise fitting installation.
explanations.C: Direction is critical; incorrect application causes tape to unwrap and fail to seal properly.
explanations.D: Tape must be applied to male threads that enter the fitting; external wrapping provides no sealing function.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What preparation is required for plastic pipe before solvent welding?

options.B: Clean, deburr, and apply primer to pipe and fitting surfaces

explanations.A: Proper preparation is essential for strong solvent weld joints; contaminants and lack of primer cause joint failure.
explanations.B: Cleaning removes contamination, deburring prevents stress concentration, and primer softens surfaces for proper solvent welding.
explanations.C: Surfaces should be smooth after deburring; excessive roughening creates voids rather than improving bonding.
explanations.D: Heat softening is not required or desirable; solvent cement chemically softens the joint area during application.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: Why must compression fittings not be over-tightened?

options.B: Over-tightening can crack the ferrule or fitting body, causing leaks
options.D: Compression fittings should be tightened as much as possible

explanations.A: Proper tightening compresses the ferrule adequately; excessive force damages components rather than improving sealing.
explanations.B: Over-tightening cracks ferrules, distorts tubing, or cracks fitting bodies, creating leaks rather than preventing them.
explanations.C: Over-tightening makes disassembly more difficult and damages ferrules making reuse impossible.
explanations.D: Manufacturer specifications provide proper tightening torque; exceeding this damages fittings and causes leaks.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What is the correct insertion depth for copper tubing into a solder fitting socket?

options.B: Fully inserted to the socket stop

explanations.A: Partial insertion reduces joint strength and creates areas where solder cannot flow, causing weak spots and leaks.
explanations.B: Full insertion ensures maximum joint overlap, proper capillary gap, and complete solder coverage for strength and leak prevention.
explanations.C: Minimal insertion provides inadequate joint area and strength; proper engagement requires full socket depth.
explanations.D: Insertion depth directly affects joint strength and reliability; full insertion is critical for proper joint performance.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: When preparing cast iron pipe for no-hub coupling installation, what is required?

options.B: Clean pipe ends and ensure they are cut square and deburred
options.C: Heat the pipe ends until red hot
options.D: Apply solder to the pipe surface

explanations.A: Cast iron for no-hub applications is not threaded; no-hub couplings seal against the smooth pipe exterior.
explanations.B: Clean, square, deburred pipe ends ensure proper gasket sealing in no-hub couplings and correct pipe alignment.
explanations.C: Heating is not required for no-hub couplings; gaskets seal at ambient temperature against clean pipe surfaces.
explanations.D: Solder is not used with cast iron no-hub couplings; elastomeric gaskets provide the seal.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What must be verified before making a threaded connection?

options.A: That threads are undamaged and properly formed
options.B: That the pipe has been painted
options.C: That the pipe is the newest available
options.D: The manufacturing date of the pipe

explanations.A: Damaged or improperly formed threads cannot create leak-free joints regardless of sealant used; inspection prevents leaks.
explanations.B: Paint must be removed from thread areas; painted threads prevent proper engagement and sealing.
explanations.C: Age is irrelevant if materials meet specifications and are in good condition; thread quality is the critical factor.
explanations.D: Manufacturing date does not affect joint quality; thread condition and proper sealant application are the critical factors.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: Why should excess flux be removed from copper joints after soldering?

options.A: Flux residue is corrosive and can cause long-term damage
options.B: Flux residue improves joint strength

explanations.A: Flux residue, especially from acid-based fluxes, is corrosive and can cause pitting and leaks over time if not removed.
explanations.B: Flux aids bonding during soldering but has no structural function after completion; residue is harmful, not beneficial.
explanations.C: While appearance is affected, the critical concern is preventing corrosion from acidic flux residue.
explanations.D: Flux removal is essential maintenance that prevents long-term corrosion damage, especially with acid-based fluxes.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: What is the purpose of chamfering the end of plastic pipe before assembly?

options.A: To make the pipe look more professional
options.B: To ease insertion and prevent gasket or O-ring damage during assembly
options.C: To increase the pipe's pressure rating

explanations.A: While chamfering may improve appearance, its functional purpose is protecting seals during assembly.
explanations.B: Chamfering creates a smooth entry that prevents sharp edges from cutting or displacing gaskets and O-rings during insertion.
explanations.C: Pressure rating is determined by material and wall thickness; chamfering affects assembly ease but not pressure capacity.
explanations.D: Material removal from chamfering is negligible; seal protection during assembly is the purpose.

questions.subtask: B-6.04 Prepares tube, tubing and pipe connections
questions.question: When preparing flared connections for copper tubing, what angle is standard for flare fittings?

options.B: 45 degrees

explanations.A: 30-degree flares are too shallow and would not match standard flare fittings, preventing proper sealing.
explanations.B: Standard flare fittings use 45-degree angles to match the mating surfaces and create proper metal-to-metal seals.
explanations.C: 60-degree flares are too steep for standard fittings and would not mate properly with 45-degree fitting cones.
explanations.D: 90-degree bends are perpendicular; flare angles are acute angles that create conical sealing surfaces.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What temperature should copper reach before applying solder to a joint?

options.B: The solder's melting temperature, indicated by solder flowing when touched to the joint

explanations.A: 100°C is too low; solder melts at much higher temperatures (typically 180-425°C depending on type).
explanations.B: The joint should be heated until it melts solder on contact, indicating proper temperature for capillary flow and bonding.
explanations.C: 500°C is excessive for most solders and may overheat the joint, damaging flux and preventing proper bonding.
explanations.D: Red hot temperature is far too high and will burn off flux, oxidize copper, and prevent proper solder bonding.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What causes a cold solder joint in copper piping?

options.B: Insufficient heating, causing poor solder flow and weak bonding

explanations.A: Excess solder may be wasteful but does not create cold joints; insufficient temperature is the cause.
explanations.B: Insufficient heating prevents solder from flowing properly into the joint through capillary action, creating weak, porous joints.
explanations.C: Excessive heating burns flux and oxidizes surfaces but creates a different problem than classic cold joints from under-heating.
explanations.D: Wrong flux may affect cleaning but cold joints specifically result from insufficient temperature for proper solder flow.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Where should the flame be directed when soldering a copper joint?

options.B: On the fitting and pipe, moving flame to heat evenly
options.C: Only on the pipe, not the fitting

explanations.A: Heating solder directly melts it before the joint reaches proper temperature, preventing capillary flow into the joint.
explanations.B: Heating both components evenly ensures proper joint temperature throughout, allowing complete solder penetration via capillary action.
explanations.C: Heating only the pipe creates uneven temperatures; the fitting must also reach solder melting temperature for complete joint filling.
explanations.D: Flux containers should be kept away from flames; heating work pieces, not materials, is proper technique.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: How can you tell when a solder joint is properly filled?

options.A: Solder appears as a complete ring around the joint
options.B: The joint changes color
options.C: Smoke stops rising from the flux

explanations.A: A complete ring of solder around the joint indicates solder has flowed through the entire capillary space, ensuring full coverage.
explanations.B: Color change indicates heating but does not confirm solder has filled the joint completely through capillary action.
explanations.C: Smoke indicates flux activity but does not confirm complete solder penetration throughout the joint gap.
explanations.D: Properly soldered joints become more secure; looseness indicates joint failure, not proper completion.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What type of solder is required for potable water systems?

options.B: Lead-free solder meeting NSF/ANSI 61 standards

explanations.A: Lead-based solders are prohibited in potable water systems due to lead leaching into drinking water.
explanations.B: Lead-free solders meeting NSF/ANSI 61 (typically 95/5 tin-antimony or similar) are required to prevent water contamination.
explanations.C: Ease of melting is not the criterion; lead-free composition meeting health standards is required for drinking water.
explanations.D: While silver solder can be used, other lead-free compositions meeting NSF/ANSI 61 are also acceptable and more common.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the advantage of using press fittings for copper tubing?

options.A: They are less expensive than solder fittings
options.B: No flame or heat required, allowing safe installation near combustibles
options.C: They work only with soft copper
options.D: They require more time than soldering

explanations.A: Press fittings are typically more expensive than solder fittings; their advantage is flame-free installation.
explanations.B: Press fittings require only a pressing tool, eliminating hot work permits and fire risks near sensitive areas.
explanations.C: Press fittings work with both rigid and soft copper; material hardness is not a limiting factor.
explanations.D: Press fittings are typically faster than soldering once the press tool is available and eliminates heat-related delays.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why must moisture be removed from copper tubing before soldering?

options.B: Steam formation prevents proper heating and solder bonding
options.C: Moisture is beneficial for the soldering process
options.D: Moisture affects only the exterior appearance

explanations.A: Moisture interferes with soldering by preventing proper temperature and causing steam; it does not aid solder flow.
explanations.B: Water turns to steam, cooling the joint and preventing proper temperature for solder flow and bonding.
explanations.C: Moisture is detrimental to soldering, preventing proper heat transfer and creating steam that disrupts solder application.
explanations.D: Moisture affects joint quality fundamentally by preventing proper heating and solder flow, not just appearance.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What happens if too much heat is applied when soldering copper?

options.B: Flux burns away and copper oxidizes, preventing proper solder bonding

explanations.A: Excessive heat damages flux protection and oxidizes copper, creating weak joints rather than strong ones.
explanations.B: Overheating burns flux, allowing oxidation that prevents solder wetting and bonding, resulting in weak or failed joints.
explanations.C: Proper temperature aids flow; excessive temperature destroys flux and oxidizes surfaces, preventing proper solder bonding.
explanations.D: Overheated joints take longer to cool due to thermal mass; excessive heat does not accelerate cooling.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: How should a compression fitting be assembled on copper tubing?

options.A: Insert tubing, then tighten nut to compress ferrule against tubing
options.B: Solder the ferrule to the tubing first
options.C: Use only hand pressure, no tools

explanations.A: Compression fittings work by nut tightening that compresses the ferrule, creating a seal against the tubing exterior.
explanations.B: Ferrules are mechanical sealing devices; soldering defeats their purpose and prevents proper compression action.
explanations.C: Proper tightening requires wrenches to compress the ferrule adequately; hand pressure is insufficient for leak-free seals.
explanations.D: Adhesives are not used in compression fittings; mechanical compression of the ferrule creates the seal.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is brazing and when is it used for copper connections?

options.A: Brazing is another name for soldering
options.B: Brazing uses higher temperature filler metals (above 450°C) for stronger joints in high-stress applications
options.C: Brazing is only for steel pipe

explanations.A: Brazing and soldering are distinct processes; brazing uses higher temperatures and produces stronger joints.
explanations.B: Brazing uses filler metals melting above 450°C, creating stronger joints for high-pressure, high-temperature, or stress applications.
explanations.C: Brazing works on various metals including copper, bronze, and steel; it is not limited to steel applications.
explanations.D: Brazing is a metal joining process using high-temperature metal filler; it does not involve plastic or adhesives.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why should copper joints be wiped clean while solder is still molten?

options.B: To remove excess solder and create a neat fillet
options.C: To test if solder has hardened

explanations.A: Wiping is for appearance and removing excess; rapid cooling can cause stress and should be avoided.
explanations.B: Wiping molten solder creates a smooth fillet, removes excess, and improves appearance without affecting joint strength.
explanations.C: Molten solder is obviously not hardened; wiping occurs while solder is still liquid to shape the fillet.
explanations.D: Flux is applied before heating; wiping occurs after soldering to shape the cooled solder fillet.

questions.subtask: B-7.01 Joins copper tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What safety precaution is essential when soldering copper indoors?

options.A: Keep a fire extinguisher nearby and ensure adequate ventilation
options.B: Work only in complete darkness

explanations.A: Fire extinguishers provide emergency protection, while ventilation removes harmful flux fumes and prevents gas accumulation.
explanations.B: Good lighting is essential for quality work and safety; darkness increases accident and fire risks.
explanations.C: Water on floors creates slip hazards and is unnecessary; proper fire watch and extinguishers are appropriate precautions.
explanations.D: Sealing spaces traps harmful fumes; adequate ventilation is required to remove flux gases and combustion products.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is solvent welding in plastic pipe joining?

options.A: Using heat to melt pipes together
options.B: Chemical process where solvent softens plastic surfaces allowing molecular bonding

explanations.A: Heat fusion is a different process; solvent welding uses chemicals, not heat, to soften and bond plastic.
explanations.B: Solvent cement chemically softens mating surfaces, allowing plastic molecules to intermingle and create a monolithic bond.
explanations.C: Threading is a mechanical joint; solvent welding creates chemical bonds between plastic surfaces.
explanations.D: Metal solders do not work on plastics; solvent welding is a plastic-specific chemical bonding process.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why must primer be applied before solvent cement on PVC and CPVC pipe?

options.A: Primer changes the pipe color only
options.B: Primer cleans and begins surface softening for better cement penetration and bonding
options.C: Primer is optional for all applications

explanations.A: While primer colors surfaces for inspection, its primary function is cleaning and preparing surfaces for bonding.
explanations.B: Primer removes contaminants, begins chemical softening, and improves solvent cement penetration for stronger joints.
explanations.C: Primer is required by most codes for PVC and CPVC pressure applications; it is not optional.
explanations.D: Primer is a chemical surface treatment that prepares bonding surfaces; it does not affect temperature.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: How long should a solvent-welded PVC joint be held together after assembly?

options.B: 10-30 seconds to allow initial bond formation
options.D: Until the cement dries completely (several hours)

explanations.A: Joints must be held to prevent separation during initial softening; immediate movement can break developing bonds.
explanations.B: Brief holding (10-30 seconds) maintains alignment during initial bonding; joints should not be disturbed for longer cure times.
explanations.C: Five minutes of manual holding is impractical; initial set occurs in seconds, though full cure takes longer.
explanations.D: Joints need brief holding for initial set; full cure occurs without manual holding over hours, but early holding prevents separation.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What ambient temperature range is acceptable for solvent welding plastic pipe?

options.B: 5°C to 40°C (40°F to 105°F) for proper cement cure

explanations.A: Temperature significantly affects solvent cement cure rate and quality; extreme temperatures compromise bonding.
explanations.B: Moderate temperatures allow proper cement flow and cure; extremes prevent adequate softening or cause overly rapid evaporation.
explanations.C: Cold temperatures slow or prevent proper cement cure and may freeze cement; joints will not bond properly.
explanations.D: High temperatures cause overly rapid solvent evaporation before proper bonding occurs, resulting in weak joints.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What indicates a properly made solvent weld joint?

options.A: No cement visible at the joint
options.B: Even bead of cement around entire joint circumference
options.C: Excessive cement dripping from the joint

explanations.A: Complete absence of visible cement may indicate insufficient application; a small even bead confirms adequate coverage.
explanations.B: An even cement bead around the joint indicates proper cement quantity and confirms the pipe was fully inserted.
explanations.C: Excessive cement waste material and may drip into the pipe, while moderate beading confirms proper application.
explanations.D: Loose fittings indicate improper assembly or damaged components; properly cemented joints are rigid.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: How should PEX tubing be connected using mechanical fittings?

options.B: Using crimp rings or expansion fittings with proper tools

explanations.A: PEX cannot be solvent welded; it requires mechanical connection methods like crimping or expansion.
explanations.B: PEX uses crimp rings compressed with crimp tools or expansion fittings with expansion tools to create secure connections.
explanations.C: PEX is not threaded; its flexibility and material properties require mechanical compression or expansion fittings.
explanations.D: PEX cannot be soldered as it melts at low temperatures; mechanical fittings are required.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What must be verified when using crimp fittings on PEX?

options.A: That the crimp is round and within tolerance using a go/no-go gauge
options.B: That the fitting is painted

explanations.A: Go/no-go gauges verify crimp dimensions are correct; improper crimps are too tight (causing leaks) or too loose (allowing separation).
explanations.B: Painting is not relevant to crimp fitting function; proper crimp dimensions ensure leak-free connections.
explanations.C: Rust indicates corrosion that weakens crimp rings; only corrosion-resistant rings should be used.
explanations.D: Loose connections indicate improper crimping or assembly; correctly crimped PEX connections are secure and leak-free.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why is proper pipe insertion depth critical in solvent-welded joints?

options.B: Full insertion ensures adequate bonding area and prevents weak spots

explanations.A: While appearance may indicate proper assembly, the critical concern is achieving adequate bonding surface area.
explanations.B: Full socket depth insertion maximizes bonding area and ensures uniform cement coverage for strong, leak-free joints.
explanations.C: Insertion depth directly affects bond area and strength; incomplete insertion creates weak joints prone to failure.
explanations.D: Shallow insertion reduces bonding area, creating weak joints that may leak or fail under pressure.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the cure time for solvent-welded PVC before pressure testing?

options.B: Minimum 15 minutes, preferably longer based on temperature and pipe size

explanations.A: Immediate testing does not allow cement to cure adequately; premature pressure can break developing bonds.
explanations.B: Minimum cure time allows solvent to evaporate and bonding to develop; larger pipes and lower temperatures require longer cure times.
explanations.C: One year is excessive; adequate cure for testing occurs in hours to days depending on conditions.
explanations.D: Pressure testing is required to verify joint integrity; cure time must be respected before testing.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What causes solvent cement to fail to bond properly?

options.A: Moisture, oil, or dirt on surfaces preventing chemical bonding
options.B: Using too much cement

explanations.A: Contamination prevents solvent from softening plastic and creating molecular bonds; clean surfaces are essential.
explanations.B: While excess cement is wasteful, inadequate surface preparation or contamination, not excess cement, causes bond failure.
explanations.C: Moderate humidity does not prevent bonding; surface contamination and extreme temperatures are the primary concerns.
explanations.D: Proper surface preparation promotes bonding; contaminated or improperly prepared surfaces cause bond failure.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why must expansion fittings for PEX use an expansion tool before assembly?

options.B: To expand the PEX tubing so it fits over the fitting, then contracts for a tight seal

explanations.A: Expansion tools enlarge PEX tubing, not fittings; the tubing expands to accept fittings then contracts.
explanations.B: Expansion tools enlarge PEX tubing diameter; PEX memory causes it to contract around fittings, creating secure connections.
explanations.C: Some expansion tools use heat, but the purpose is expanding tubing to fit over fittings, not heating fittings directly.
explanations.D: PEX is not threaded; expansion fittings rely on PEX memory to contract around fittings after expansion.

questions.subtask: B-7.02 Joins plastic tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What type of cement is used for ABS plastic pipe?

options.A: PVC cement works for all plastics
options.B: ABS-specific solvent cement formulated for ABS plastic

explanations.A: Different plastics require specific cement formulations; PVC cement may not properly bond ABS.
explanations.B: ABS cement is formulated to dissolve and bond ABS plastic; using incorrect cement results in weak or failed joints.
explanations.C: While epoxies exist for some applications, solvent cement specific to ABS is the standard joining method.
explanations.D: Contact cement is for surface bonding of materials; solvent cement creates chemical bonds in plastic pipe.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: How many threads should be engaged in a proper threaded steel pipe joint?

options.B: Typically 4-6 threads for structural integrity and sealing
options.C: All available threads on the pipe

explanations.A: One or two threads provide insufficient engagement for strength or sealing; joints will leak and fail.
explanations.B: 4-6 threads (approximately 1/2 to 3/4 inch engagement) provide adequate strength and sealing for most applications.
explanations.C: Complete thread engagement is excessive and indicates measurement errors; proper engagement leaves 1-2 threads visible.
explanations.D: Thread engagement is critical for both mechanical strength and leak prevention in threaded pipe systems.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What indicates a properly made threaded joint?

options.B: Proper tightness with 1-2 threads visible past the fitting
options.D: Excessive thread sealant oozing from joint

explanations.A: Stripped threads indicate over-tightening or defective threads; proper joints maintain thread integrity.
explanations.B: Properly assembled joints are tight with 1-2 threads visible, indicating correct engagement without over-tightening.
explanations.C: Free spinning indicates insufficient tightening or damaged threads; proper joints are snug and sealed.
explanations.D: Moderate sealant squeeze-out is normal, but excessive amounts indicate over-application rather than confirming proper assembly.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of using two pipe wrenches when assembling threaded pipe?

options.B: One wrench tightens while the other holds back-up to prevent unintended rotation

explanations.A: While two wrenches may be efficient, their primary purpose is preventing unwanted rotation of connected components.
explanations.B: Back-up wrenches prevent rotation that could loosen previously assembled joints or damage connected equipment.
explanations.C: While two wrenches provide control, their critical function is maintaining already-assembled joints while adding new connections.
explanations.D: Back-up wrenches are essential when tightening fittings on assembled systems to prevent disturbing existing joints.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What preparation is required for welding steel pipe?

options.B: Clean, bevel, and align pipe ends properly

explanations.A: Welding requires careful preparation to ensure complete fusion, proper penetration, and structural integrity.
explanations.B: Cleaning removes contamination, beveling allows weld penetration, and alignment ensures proper fit-up for quality welds.
explanations.C: Paint must be removed before welding; coating contamination creates poor welds and releases toxic fumes.
explanations.D: Threading and welding are separate joining methods; pipe is not threaded when welded joints are used.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What fitting type is used for connecting pipes of different sizes in threaded systems?

options.B: Reducer or bushing

explanations.A: Couplings join pipes of the same size; reducers are needed for size changes.
explanations.B: Reducers (gradual transition) and bushings (abrupt transition) connect different pipe sizes in threaded systems.
explanations.C: Unions allow disassembly but do not change pipe size; reducers or bushings are needed for size transitions.
explanations.D: Caps close pipe ends and do not facilitate connections between pipes of different sizes.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why are unions used in threaded pipe systems?

options.B: To allow disassembly without cutting pipe or unthreading entire runs

explanations.A: Unions connect same-size pipes; reducers or bushings are used for size changes.
explanations.B: Unions provide removable connections for maintenance, allowing systems to be disassembled without disturbing other joints.
explanations.C: Unions do not significantly affect flow; their purpose is facilitating disassembly and reassembly.
explanations.D: Unions are specifically designed for temporary disassembly; permanent joints use couplings or welding.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What must be done to prevent galvanic corrosion when joining steel pipe to copper?

options.B: Use dielectric unions or insulators to electrically isolate dissimilar metals
options.D: Galvanic corrosion is not a concern

explanations.A: Paint may slow corrosion but does not prevent galvanic action; electrical isolation is required.
explanations.B: Dielectric unions with insulating gaskets prevent electrical current flow between dissimilar metals, eliminating galvanic corrosion.
explanations.C: Thread sealant provides leak prevention but does not insulate metals electrically or prevent galvanic corrosion.
explanations.D: Galvanic corrosion actively occurs when dissimilar metals contact in the presence of electrolyte; isolation is essential.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the advantage of grooved mechanical couplings for steel pipe?

options.B: Fast installation without threading or welding, with some flexibility for movement

explanations.A: Grooved couplings are available in various pressure ratings; they do not inherently have lower ratings than threaded joints.
explanations.B: Grooved couplings install quickly with basic tools, require no threading or welding, and allow some angular deflection.
explanations.C: Grooved couplings require minimal surface preparation compared to welding; pipe ends need grooving but not extensive prep.
explanations.D: Grooved couplings are designed for disassembly; removal requires only unbolting for maintenance access.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What issue can occur if excessive force is used when tightening threaded steel pipe?

options.A: Threads can be stripped or fittings cracked
options.B: The joint becomes easier to disassemble

explanations.A: Excessive torque strips threads, cracks fittings (especially cast iron), and damages joints rather than improving sealing.
explanations.B: Over-tightening makes disassembly more difficult and can gall threads, potentially requiring cutting.
explanations.C: Proper torque optimizes sealant performance; excessive force can squeeze out sealant or damage threads.
explanations.D: Flexibility is a material property; over-tightening damages threads and fittings rather than affecting flexibility.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why is black steel pipe often used for gas systems instead of galvanized pipe?

options.B: Galvanizing can flake internally and cause blockages in gas systems
options.C: Black pipe has higher pressure ratings

explanations.A: While cost may be a factor, the primary technical reason is preventing zinc flaking in gas applications.
explanations.B: Galvanized coating can flake off inside pipe, potentially blocking orifices in gas valves and appliances.
explanations.C: Pressure ratings depend on schedule and size, not coating; both materials are available in equivalent ratings.
explanations.D: Color indicates coating type; the concern is zinc coating behavior in gas systems, not appearance preference.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of a pipe flange?

options.B: To provide bolted connections for valves, equipment, and pipes requiring frequent disassembly

explanations.A: Flanges add weight and material; their purpose is providing removable connections, not weight reduction.
explanations.B: Flanges create strong, leak-tight connections that can be disassembled for maintenance on valves, equipment, and piping.
explanations.C: Flanges do not significantly affect flow velocity; they provide mechanical connection capability.
explanations.D: Flanges serve functional purposes in creating removable pressure-tight connections, not decorative roles.

questions.subtask: B-7.03 Joins steel tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What gasket material is commonly used for flanged steel pipe connections?

options.B: Rubber, fiber, or spiral-wound gaskets depending on service conditions

explanations.A: Paper products lack the strength and chemical resistance required for pressure piping applications.
explanations.B: Gasket selection depends on pressure, temperature, and media; rubber, fiber, and spiral-wound types suit different conditions.
explanations.C: Aluminum foil lacks the compressibility, resilience, and conformability required for reliable flange sealing.
explanations.D: Plastic film cannot withstand pressures, temperatures, or chemical exposure in piping systems.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What is the traditional joining method for hub and spigot cast iron pipe?

options.B: Lead and oakum caulking in the hub

explanations.A: Cast iron drainage pipe is typically not threaded; hub and spigot or no-hub methods are standard.
explanations.B: Traditional joints use oakum packing and molten lead poured and caulked in the hub to seal against the spigot.
explanations.C: Solder cannot bond to cast iron and lacks the strength required for drainage applications.
explanations.D: Adhesives are not suitable for cast iron; mechanical packing or modern no-hub couplings are used.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What modern alternative has largely replaced lead and oakum joints?

options.B: No-hub couplings with neoprene gaskets and stainless steel clamps

explanations.A: Solvent welding is for plastic pipe; cast iron requires mechanical or compression-type joints.
explanations.B: No-hub couplings with elastomeric gaskets and clamps provide fast, reliable, lead-free joints for cast iron.
explanations.C: Cast iron drainage pipe is not typically threaded; no-hub and hubbed joints with modern gaskets are standard.
explanations.D: Wire binding provides no sealing capability; proper compression couplings with gaskets are required.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: How should no-hub couplings be installed on cast iron pipe?

options.A: Position gasket and shield over joint, tighten clamps to specified torque
options.B: Weld the coupling to the pipe
options.C: Use solder to attach the coupling

explanations.A: No-hub installation requires centering the gasket over the joint, positioning the stainless shield, and torquing clamps properly.
explanations.B: Welding is not used with no-hub couplings; the system relies on compression of gaskets by clamps.
explanations.C: Solder does not bond to cast iron and cannot provide the mechanical compression needed for no-hub seals.
explanations.D: Nails cannot provide the uniform compression force required; torqued clamps compress gaskets properly.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What is the advantage of no-hub couplings over traditional lead joints?

options.B: Faster installation, no hot work, eliminates lead exposure hazards
options.C: No-hub joints are permanent and cannot be disassembled
options.D: No-hub joints only work on small diameter pipe

explanations.A: No-hub couplings are generally lighter than lead joints and easier to handle during installation.
explanations.B: No-hub couplings install quickly without torches, eliminate lead exposure, and meet modern safety standards.
explanations.C: No-hub couplings can be disassembled by removing clamps; they provide maintenance access unlike lead joints.
explanations.D: No-hub couplings are available in all standard cast iron pipe sizes from small to large diameters.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What must be verified before tightening no-hub coupling clamps?

options.A: That pipe ends are clean, aligned, and gasket is centered on joint
options.B: That the pipe is painted
options.C: That excessive gap exists between pipes

explanations.A: Clean aligned pipes with centered gaskets ensure proper sealing; contamination or misalignment causes leaks.
explanations.B: Paint should be removed from joint areas to ensure proper gasket contact; painted surfaces can prevent sealing.
explanations.C: Excessive gaps prevent proper gasket compression and sealing; pipes should abut or have minimal gap per specifications.
explanations.D: Torn or damaged gaskets must be replaced; they cannot seal properly regardless of clamp tightness.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What is the purpose of a rubber gasket compression joint in cast iron soil pipe?

options.B: Gasket compresses into hub providing flexible, watertight seal

explanations.A: Gaskets are functional components that create seals; appearance is not their purpose.
explanations.B: Compression gaskets seated in hubs create flexible watertight seals that accommodate minor movement and misalignment.
explanations.C: Gaskets add negligible weight; their purpose is creating flexible, reliable seals in hubbed cast iron joints.
explanations.D: Gasket sealing is the entire purpose of compression joints; they replace lead and oakum for sealing.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: Why must cast iron joints allow for some movement?

options.B: To accommodate building settlement, thermal expansion, and vibration without cracking

explanations.A: Cast iron is rigid and brittle; joints must accommodate movement to prevent fracture from building settling or thermal changes.
explanations.B: Flexible joints accommodate inevitable building movement, preventing stress concentration and fracture in rigid cast iron.
explanations.C: While flexible joints may ease installation, their primary purpose is allowing movement after installation.
explanations.D: Movement allowance is a functional requirement for long-term integrity, not a cost reduction strategy.

questions.subtask: B-7.04 Joins cast iron pipe
questions.question: What support spacing is typically required for horizontal cast iron pipe?

options.B: Every 1.5-3 meters (5-10 feet) depending on size
options.C: No support needed due to pipe weight

explanations.A: 10-meter spacing is excessive for cast iron; the pipe's weight and brittleness require closer support spacing.
explanations.B: Cast iron requires support every 1.5-3 meters depending on diameter to prevent sagging and joint stress.
explanations.C: Heavy weight makes support more critical, not less; unsupported cast iron sags and stresses joints.
explanations.D: Supporting only at joints leaves long unsupported spans that will sag and stress connections.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What joining method is used for stainless steel tubing in sanitary applications?

options.B: Orbital welding or tri-clamp fittings for smooth, cleanable surfaces

explanations.A: While threading is possible, sanitary applications typically use welding or clamp fittings to avoid crevices where bacteria can grow.
explanations.B: Orbital welding creates smooth interior surfaces, while tri-clamp fittings allow disassembly, both meeting sanitary requirements.
explanations.C: Solvent welding is for plastic pipe; stainless steel requires mechanical or fusion welding methods.
explanations.D: Wire ties provide no pressure containment or sanitary sealing; proper welding or compression fittings are required.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is unique about joining HDPE (high-density polyethylene) pipe?

options.B: Heat fusion welding melts surfaces together creating monolithic joints

explanations.A: HDPE cannot be solvent welded with PVC cement; it requires heat fusion or mechanical fittings.
explanations.B: HDPE fusion welding heats mating surfaces to melting point, creating seamless molecular bonds stronger than the pipe.
explanations.C: HDPE is not threaded for pressure applications; heat fusion or mechanical compression fittings are used.
explanations.D: HDPE can be joined effectively through heat fusion or mechanical fittings appropriate for its properties.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is a press fitting connection for copper or stainless steel?

options.B: Special fitting mechanically pressed onto pipe using hydraulic tools

explanations.A: Press fittings are not threaded; they use mechanical deformation to create leak-tight seals.
explanations.B: Press fittings with O-ring seals are mechanically compressed onto pipe using hydraulic press tools, creating permanent connections.
explanations.C: Press fittings use mechanical compression, not solder; they eliminate hot work and flux.
explanations.D: Adhesives are not used; mechanical compression of fittings with internal seals creates leak-tight joints.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why is proper preparation critical for electrofusion welding of plastic pipe?

options.B: Contamination prevents proper molecular bonding during electrical heating

explanations.A: Electrofusion requires careful surface preparation; contamination prevents the molecular bonding necessary for leak-free joints.
explanations.B: Oils, dirt, and oxidation prevent proper molecular bonding during electrofusion; clean prepared surfaces ensure strong joints.
explanations.C: While appearance may be affected, the critical concern is achieving complete molecular fusion for leak-free pressure-tight joints.
explanations.D: Proper preparation may take time but ensures successful fusion; shortcuts result in weak or leaking joints.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What advantage do push-fit fittings offer for copper and plastic pipe?

options.A: They only work with one pipe size
options.B: No tools, heat, or solvents required - pipe simply pushes into fitting
options.C: They are permanent and cannot be removed
options.D: They require extensive training to use

explanations.A: Push-fit fittings are available in various sizes compatible with multiple pipe materials and diameters.
explanations.B: Push-fit fittings use internal grip rings and O-rings, allowing instant connections by simply pushing pipe into the fitting.
explanations.C: Many push-fit fittings are removable using release tools; they provide convenient disconnection for repairs.
explanations.D: Push-fit simplicity is their advantage; minimal training is needed compared to soldering or welding.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What consideration is important when joining different types of plastic pipe?

options.A: All plastics can be joined with any cement
options.B: Transition fittings or mechanical couplings compatible with both materials must be used
options.C: Plastic pipes cannot be joined to each other

explanations.A: Different plastics require specific cements; not all solvent cements work with all plastic types.
explanations.B: Different plastics may require transition fittings, mechanical connections, or universal cements specifically approved for multi-material use.
explanations.C: Plastics can be joined using appropriate transition methods including mechanical couplings and approved cement systems.
explanations.D: Material compatibility, not color, determines appropriate joining methods; chemical compatibility is critical.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is a flanged connection used for in specialized piping?

options.B: To create bolted joints for valves, equipment, and pipes requiring periodic disassembly

explanations.A: Flanges create removable bolted connections, not permanent welds; they enable disassembly for maintenance.
explanations.B: Flanged connections allow equipment removal for maintenance, inspection, or replacement without cutting pipe.
explanations.C: Flanges serve critical functional roles in creating pressure-tight removable connections, not decorative purposes.
explanations.D: Flanges add weight and material; their purpose is providing removable connections, not weight reduction.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why must specialized gaskets be used with corrosive chemical piping?

options.B: Standard gaskets may be chemically attacked, causing system leaks and failures
options.D: Gaskets are not needed with chemicals

explanations.A: Chemical resistance is a functional safety requirement, not an appearance consideration.
explanations.B: Incompatible gasket materials dissolve, swell, or degrade when exposed to chemicals, causing dangerous leaks.
explanations.C: Chemical-compatible gaskets may cost more but are required for safety and system integrity, not to increase cost.
explanations.D: Chemical systems require gaskets compatible with the specific chemicals; material selection is critical for safety.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What is butt fusion welding used for in plastic pipe installation?

options.B: Joining large diameter thermoplastic pipes by heating and pressing ends together
options.D: It is never used in plumbing

explanations.A: Butt fusion is particularly common for larger diameter pipes where its strength advantages and efficiency are significant.
explanations.B: Butt fusion heats pipe ends to melting point, then presses them together under controlled pressure, creating strong seamless joints.
explanations.C: Butt fusion is specifically for thermoplastic materials like HDPE and polypropylene, not metal.
explanations.D: Butt fusion is widely used for water mains, industrial piping, and geothermal installations.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What determines the appropriate torque for bolted flange connections?

options.B: Flange size, pressure rating, gasket type, and manufacturer specifications
options.C: Tighten as much as possible always

explanations.A: Torque specifications are engineering requirements based on materials and conditions, not personal judgment.
explanations.B: Proper torque depends on size, rating, and gasket material; specifications ensure adequate sealing without damage.
explanations.C: Over-torquing crushes gaskets, warps flanges, and can break bolts; proper specified torque is essential.
explanations.D: Correct torque is critical for creating uniform gasket compression and leak-free joints without damage.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: What safety consideration is important when working with glass or lined pipe?

options.B: Extreme care to prevent scratches and impacts that could cause catastrophic failure

explanations.A: Glass and lined pipes require special handling due to brittleness and sensitivity to mechanical damage.
explanations.B: Scratches, impacts, or thermal shock can cause cracks leading to sudden failure; careful handling is essential.
explanations.C: Glass and linings are brittle and sensitive to mechanical and thermal stress; they require careful handling.
explanations.D: Safety, not appearance, is the critical concern; damage can cause sudden catastrophic failure with potential injury.

questions.subtask: B-7.05 Joins specialized tube, tubing and pipe
questions.question: Why are expansion joints important in long runs of specialized piping?

options.B: To accommodate thermal expansion and contraction, preventing stress and joint failure

explanations.A: Expansion joints serve critical functional roles in managing thermal movement, not decorative purposes.
explanations.B: Long pipe runs experience significant thermal expansion; expansion joints prevent stress buildup that would cause leaks or failure.
explanations.C: Expansion joints are necessary to prevent damage from thermal movement; their cost is justified by preventing failures.
explanations.D: Expansion joints are essential in systems experiencing temperature changes to prevent stress-related failures.
